{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3589632,"name":"","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/e79b87/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-12T02:43:00.767Z","cooked":"

My team is in the process of expanding our auton paths. The way we manage our autons is by pulling all of our choreo paths from the deploy directory into a dictionary that stores the name and the choreo trajectory on RobotInit. This past week, when upgrading our autons, we went from 7 unique path segments (each around 20 KB) to 20. After this, we noticed that our autons became much more jumpy and unresponsive, and even in teleop, we sometimes get periods of up to 2 seconds where the bot becomes unresponsive.

At the moment we’re unsure if this is a radio issue or a RoboRIO issue (We have a RoboRIO 2.0, both the radio and RIO run the latest firmware). If anyone is familiar enough with robotpy and could let us know how large chunks of memory are allocated, that’d be greatly appreciated!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"updated_at":"2025-04-12T02:52:53.173Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":120,"readers_count":119,"score":33.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":498972,"topic_slug":"roborio-ram-limits-with-robotpy","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":false},{"id":3589731,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-12T04:57:24.785Z","cooked":"

I created an issue to discuss RAM related things at NumPy/pathplannerlib memory issues · Issue #149 · robotpy/mostrobotpy · GitHub, there are a variety of things you can disable to get more RAM.

However, what you’re describing doesn’t really sound like RAM problems – the RoboRIO doesn’t have swap memory, so when you run out of memory things tend to just crash instead of getting slow and jumpy. I can’t imagine the radio has any effect on this either.

You should try the old code and ensure the problem actually goes away. You might have a loose CAN wire thats causing problems (you can also check the logs for errors).

If the old code works and the new code doesn’t, then obviously something changed. Adding new segments implies that something isn’t scaling well with the new segments – maybe there’s a linear search somewhere, or some other inefficiency in your code or in pathplanner (I don’t think anyone has really looked very hard at it from an efficiency perspective). If you have simulation set up, running profiling on the old and new versions of the code and comparing the results might highlight where the problem is.

Thank you so much. The problem went away when testing the old code. We may try profiling today, but we’ll try some of your other suggestions first.

I just checked and we were pulling 83 Choreo trajectories in on startup. I never saw any memory issue with it. Ours are all around 20k in filesize too.

You could ssh in as lvuser@10.te.am.2 and run free -m to check the RoboRIO’s memory usage after things have started up.
